brief_description: Mechanistic study of why elevated tumor suppressor ARF expression in aggressive subtypes of Muscle-invasive bladder cancer (MIBC) is associated with poor outcome and attenuated response to chemotherapy (cisplatin).  The study was investigated In both GEMM and murine xenograft models of human MIBC.  Resistance was mediated in part by the integrin-binding protein ITGB3BP (CENPR) and reflected ARF-dependent impairment of protein translation, which was exaggerated by drug treatment.
brief_title: AFR in drug resistance of cisplatin in bladder cancer
description: Mechanistic study of why elevated tumor suppressor ARF expression in aggressive subtypes of Muscle-invasive bladder cancer (MIBC) is associated with poor outcome and attenuated response to chemotherapy (cisplatin).  The study was investigated In both GEMM and murine xenograft models of human MIBC.  Resistance was mediated in part by the integrin-binding protein ITGB3BP (CENPR) and reflected ARF-dependent impairment of protein translation, which was exaggerated by drug treatment.
endpoints: Inducible Arf(f/f) GEM model in the context of p53(f/f) and Pten(f/f). RNAseq_GE, cisplatin response report, protein translation assay, and H&E and IHC.
hypothesis: From drug resistance  association studies, we considered the possibility that ARF overexpression might play a causal role in failed MIBC chemotherapy.
objectives: To investigate whether dysregulation of ARF results in adverse outcome or impaired treatment response in MIBC of both GEMM and xenograft models.
official_title: ARF Confers a Context-Dependent Response to Chemotherapy in Muscle-Invasive Bladder Cancer
